tn.text: "Yahweh spoke his word." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:01:01|1:1]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: What do you mean, you who use this proverb ... 'Fathers eat sour grapes, and the children's teeth are made blunt?'
tn.text: God is rebuking the people for thinking that they are being punished for their parent's sins, but believe they themselves are sinless. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Fathers eat sour grapes, and the children's teeth are made blunt
tn.text: This proverbs means that children are punished because of their parents' wicked deeds. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_proverbs]])
This refers to the people of Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The word "behold" here adds emphasis to what follows. It can also be translated as "Indeed!" This can also be translated as "Look!" or "Listen!" or "Pay attention to what I am about to tell you!"

tn.ref: has not eaten on the mountains ... has not lifted up his eyes to the idols
tn.text: These phrases refer to idol worship. People ate the food at the mountain shrines to honor the idols. The phrase "lifted up his eyes" refers to looking at the idols and honoring them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
God is impressed by lenders who return the pledge back to the borrower before the borrower actually pays the lender back.

tn.ref: gives his food to the hungry. and that he covers the naked with clothes
tn.text: God is impressed by those who are generous towards those who lack food and cloths.
Yahweh continues to describe the actions of the righteous man.
This word refers to the money paid by a person to use borrowed money. However, some modern versions interpret "any interest" in this passage as "too much interest."

tn.ref: this is the Lord Yahweh's declaration
tn.text: See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:05:11|5:11]].

This refers to the sinful actions mentioned in 18:11-[[:en:bible:notes:ezk:18:12|18:13]].
Yahweh continues to speak about the violent son.
The words "poor" and "needy" emphasize that these are people who cannot help themselves. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.text: This phrase means he is responsible for his own death. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Giving clothes to people who need them is spoken of as if it were placing the clothes on their bodies. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: he draws his hand back from the poor
tn.text: Here "hand" stands for committing unjust actions. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This word refers to the money paid by a person to use borrowed money. However, some modern versions interpret "interest" in this passage as "too much interest."

tn.ref: Why does the son not bear the iniquity
tn.text: AT: "Why is the son not responsible for the iniquity"

tn.ref: The righteousness of the one who acts rightly will be on himself
tn.text: AT: "The one who does what is right will be considered righteous"

tn.ref: the wickedness of the wicked person will be on himself
tn.text: AT: "the one who does what is wicked will be considered wicked"
Yahweh speaking of the wicked person who changes and does what is righteous.
AT: "be remembered" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: He will live by the righteousness that he practices
tn.text: He will continue to live because he does the right things"
Yahweh speaking about his desire for wicked people.

tn.ref: Do I greatly rejoice over the death of the wicked ... and not in his turning away from his way so that he may live?
tn.text: "I do not greatly rejoice over the death of the wicked, but I do rejoice if he turns away from his evil actions and lives" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: this is the Lord Yahweh's declaration
tn.text: See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:05:11|5:11]].

tn.ref: not in his turning away from his way
tn.text: "not changing from his sinful actions to do what is right. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Yahweh gives an example of a man who turns from righteousness to wickedness.
AT: "he must die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: will not be called to mind
tn.text: AT: "will not be remembered" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
crime done against a country or against God, by someone who is expected to be loyal.

tn.ref: So he will die in the sins that he commits
tn.text: AT: "Therefore, he will die for the sins he committed."

tn.ref: dies because of them ... die in the iniquity that he has done
tn.text: These phrases repeat the thought of a man dying because of his sin to express that it was his fault and the fault of no one else. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
he has realized something. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Yahweh continues to teach the people of Israel why his way is fair.

tn.ref: How is my way not fair, house of Israel?
tn.text: "My way is certainly fair, people of Israel." (See [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]]).

tn.ref: How is your way not unfair?
tn.text: "How is your way fair?" or "It is your way that is not fair." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: each man among you according to his ways
tn.text: "the actions of each man."
